In the event that multiple studies meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them leads to the policy changes described.

title: Will the Democratic Party (US) implement a policy that significantly influences social sciences research by 2025?
Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation to regulate artificial intelligence by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly regulates artificial intelligence (AI). For the purposes of this question, "significant legislation" is defined as a law or set of laws that establish comprehensive federal guidelines, standards, or requirements for the development, deployment, and ethical use of AI technologies across multiple sectors. The legislation must be more substantial than minor amendments to existing laws and must address at least three of the following areas: ethical guidelines, privacy protection, transparency and accountability, bias and discrimination, and security measures. The passage of the legislation must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) are sufficient. If multiple pieces of legislation are passed that collectively meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes. In the event of a partial or sector-specific regulation that does not meet the comprehensive criteria outlined, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will China lead the world in quantum computing research by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, China is recognized as the global leader in quantum computing research. Leadership in quantum computing research is defined by the following criteria:

- Publication Volume: China must have the highest number of peer-reviewed scientific publications in the field of quantum computing, compared to any other country.
- Technological Breakthroughs: China must have achieved at least one significant technological breakthrough in quantum computing that is recognized by the international scientific community.
- International Collaborations: China must be involved in the most significant international collaborations in quantum computing research.

Recognition of China's leadership position must come from authoritative sources in the scientific community, such as the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), the International Quantum Computing Association (IQCA), or similar organizations. In the absence of a clear consensus, a survey of recent publications in top scientific journals (e.g., Nature, Science, IEEE Transactions on Quantum Engineering) will be used to determine leadership.

In the event of a tie in any of the criteria, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Scott Alexander publish a groundbreaking paper on algorithmic game theory by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Scott Alexander (author of the Slate Star Codex and Astral Codex Ten blogs) has published a paper on algorithmic game theory that is recognized as groundbreaking by the academic community. A paper is considered "groundbreaking" if it introduces novel concepts, methods, or applications that significantly advance the field of algorithmic game theory, and is cited as such in at least three peer-reviewed academic journals within a year of its publication. The paper must be published in a peer-reviewed academic journal or presented at a major academic conference in the field of game theory or computer science. In the absence of direct academic recognition, a consensus among recognized experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources or academic blogs, will suffice. The resolution will default to No if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

title: Will robotics achieve a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology by 2025?
Will a new technology emerge by 2025 that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new technology has been developed that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases. Significant improvement is defined as:
- A reduction in detection time by at least 50% compared to the best available technology as of 2023.
- An increase in detection accuracy to at least 95%.
- A treatment method that reduces recovery time by at least 30% or increases the survival rate by at least 20% for diseases with a mortality rate higher than 1%.
The emergence of such technology must be confirmed through publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official announcement from a recognized health organization (e.g., WHO, CDC). In the absence of such announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Technologies that are still in the experimental or trial phase by the end of 2025 do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will NATO expand to include any new member countries by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) officially expands to include one or more new member countries. Expansion is defined as the formal acceptance of a new member country's application by existing NATO members, culminating in the official signing of the NATO accession protocol by the new member country. The resolution will be based on official announcements from NATO or its member countries. In the absence of direct announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The question will resolve as No if no new member countries are officially added to NATO by the specified date. Temporary partnerships, cooperation agreements, or dialogue forums do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges with a global infection rate exceeding 1% of the world's population. The disease must be identified and confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population that has been confirmed infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO, CDC, or a consensus of reputable global health organizations. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the three most cited figures will be used to determine the resolution. The disease must be a newly identified infectious agent, not a variant of an existing disease. In case of re-emergence of a disease not seen in over 50 years, it will be considered 'new' for the purposes of this question.

title: Will significant advancements in climatology lead to a major shift in global climate policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, significant advancements in climatology result in a major shift in global climate policy. A "significant advancement" is defined as a breakthrough in climate science that leads to a new understanding of climate dynamics, significantly improves climate modeling accuracy, or provides a novel approach to climate change mitigation or adaptation. A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, global agreements or treaties aimed at climate change mitigation or adaptation, with commitments beyond those established in the Paris Agreement. The shift must be recognized by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) or a similar authoritative body. The adoption of new policies by major greenhouse gas emitting countries (top 10 emitters) that significantly exceed their previous commitments under the Paris Agreement will also qualify as a major shift. The resolution will rely on announcements from authoritative sources, such as the UNFCCC, and coverage by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

title: Will Canada introduce a new digital privacy law by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Canada has officially introduced a new digital privacy law. The law must be enacted by the Canadian Parliament and come into force, addressing digital privacy concerns within the jurisdiction of Canada. The introduction of the law must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (CBC, The Globe and Mail, National Post, Toronto Star, Reuters) are sufficient. The law must specifically address the collection, storage, and use of personal data by both public and private entities, and include provisions for the protection of citizens' digital privacy rights. Temporary measures or amendments to existing laws without the introduction of a new, comprehensive digital privacy law do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a landmark legal case involving AI ethics be adjudicated by the Supreme Court before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the Supreme Court of the United States adjudicates a case that is widely recognized as a landmark in the field of AI ethics. A "landmark case" is defined as a case that sets a significant precedent or substantially influences the development of law in the area of artificial intelligence and ethics. The case must involve core ethical issues related to artificial intelligence, such as algorithmic bias, AI accountability, privacy concerns, or the ethical treatment of AI entities. The adjudication must be final, without the possibility of further appeal on the merits of the case. Resolution will be based on official court documents or announcements. In the absence of such documents, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Guardian) will be sufficient for resolution. In the event that multiple cases could qualify, the question will resolve as Yes upon the adjudication of the first case that meets these criteria.

title: Will a major environmental lawsuit against a global corporation be won in a US court by 2025?
Will Taiwan pass a new digital privacy law that aligns with the European Union's GDPR standards by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Taiwan has passed and enacted a new digital privacy law that aligns with the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) standards. The law must include, at a minimum, provisions for user consent, rights to access and delete personal data, and strict data protection measures for personal data of Taiwan's residents. The passage of the law must be confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The law must be fully operational and enforceable by the specified date. Interim or draft laws, or laws that only partially meet GDPR standards, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a landmark legal case in the sports industry, specifically involving basketball, set a new precedent for athlete contracts by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a landmark legal case in the sports industry, specifically involving basketball, has been adjudicated, resulting in a new precedent for athlete contracts. A "landmark legal case" is defined as a case that is widely recognized within the legal and sports communities for its significance in altering the standard practices, terms, or conditions of athlete contracts in professional basketball. The case must be cited by major sports law publications and recognized by a consensus of legal experts as having set a new precedent. The resolution will be based on reports from reputable news sources (e.g., ESPN, Sports Illustrated, The Athletic) or official statements from professional basketball leagues (NBA, EuroLeague, etc.). In the absence of clear public announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations are required. The new precedent must be applicable and enforced in at least one professional basketball league.

title: Will China implement a comprehensive legal framework for regulating artificial intelligence by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the People's Republic of China has officially implemented a comprehensive legal framework for the regulation of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. A "comprehensive legal framework" is defined as legislation that addresses a broad range of AI-related issues, including but not limited to: ethical guidelines, development standards, usage policies, privacy concerns, and security measures. The framework must be applicable across multiple sectors where AI is used, such as healthcare, finance, transportation, and public services. The implementation of such a framework must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. In the event of partial or sector-specific regulations being implemented without a broader framework, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Brazil achieve a 20% reduction in deforestation rates by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Brazil has achieved a 20% reduction in deforestation rates compared to the baseline year of 2020. The deforestation rates will be measured by the official data published by Brazil's National Institute for Space Research (INPE) or any other authoritative source designated by the Brazilian government. The measurement will consider the annual rate of deforestation in the Amazon rainforest, as this region is the primary focus of deforestation efforts and policies in Brazil. In the event that INPE or the designated authoritative source does not publish data for 2025 by the resolution date, the question will resolve using the most recent data available. If there is a significant discrepancy between different authoritative sources, the question will resolve based on a consensus of the cited sources. Temporary fluctuations in deforestation rates that do not reflect a sustained reduction will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Taiwan introduce a new policy to reduce plastic waste by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Taiwan has officially introduced a new policy aimed at reducing plastic waste. The policy must be aimed at significantly reducing the production, use, or disposal of plastic materials across any sector (e.g., retail, manufacturing, food service). The introduction of the policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy must be enacted and in force, not merely proposed or in a planning stage. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes if the policy is intended for nationwide application.

title: Will Google achieve carbon neutrality in its global operations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Google has officially achieved carbon neutrality in its global operations. Carbon neutrality must be verified by an independent, reputable third-party organization recognized for environmental or carbon accounting standards, such as The Greenhouse Gas Protocol, CDP (formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project), or equivalent. The achievement must encompass all of Google's operations worldwide, including data centers, offices, and any other facilities. The verification process must confirm that Google has effectively balanced its carbon emissions by reducing them to net-zero through a combination of emissions reduction initiatives and offsetting remaining emissions with renewable energy investments, carbon capture technologies, or other recognized carbon offset mechanisms. In the absence of a direct announcement from Google, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient for resolution. Temporary or partial achievements, such as reaching carbon neutrality in a single country or for a specific type of operation, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major cryptocurrency be named after a cricket term by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a cryptocurrency that is ranked within the top 100 by market capitalization according to a recognized cryptocurrency market analysis platform (e.g., CoinMarketCap, CoinGecko) is named after a term commonly used in the sport of cricket. The term must be directly associated with cricket and not merely a common word that could apply to multiple contexts. The name of the cryptocurrency must be officially recognized and used in transactions, marketing, and communications by its creators or managing entity. In the event that multiple cryptocurrencies meet this criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of them is within the top 100 by market capitalization. Cryptocurrencies that are named after cricket terms but do not meet the market capitalization requirement or are not officially recognized as being named after cricket terms will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the value of Bitcoin exceed the US dollar in terms of global transaction volume by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the total global transaction volume of Bitcoin exceeds that of the US dollar. Transaction volume refers to the total value of all transactions processed in the respective currencies within a given year. The assessment will be based on data reported by authoritative financial institutions or organizations specializing in cryptocurrency analytics, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, Chainalysis, or CoinMetrics. In the absence of direct data, credible estimates from at least three reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Financial Times, The Wall Street Journal) will be considered. The resolution will consider only legitimate transactions, excluding those associated with illegal activities, as verified by the aforementioned sources. In the event of conflicting reports, the consensus among the majority of credible sources will determine the outcome. The question resolves as YES if Bitcoin's transaction volume for the year 2030 exceeds that of the US dollar, as determined by the specified criteria.

title: Will Australia introduce a national cryptocurrency by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Australia has officially introduced a national cryptocurrency. The introduction of such a cryptocurrency must be confirmed by an official government announcement or legislation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The cryptocurrency must be recognized as legal tender by the Australian government and available for use by the general public. In the event of a pilot program or limited release, the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, documented plan for nationwide rollout within a reasonable timeframe. Temporary or experimental deployments do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the United Kingdom launch a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially launched a new national health initiative specifically aimed at combating future pandemics. The initiative must be a comprehensive program that includes, but is not limited to, measures for rapid disease detection, vaccine development and distribution, public health education, and international cooperation. The launch of the initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must be new, distinct from and more comprehensive than existing programs as of 2023.

title: Will a major ethical controversy in medical research lead to global policy changes in health care by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major ethical controversy in medical research leads to the implementation of new global health care policies or significant amendments to existing ones. A "major ethical controversy" is defined as an event or series of events in medical research that raises significant ethical concerns, receives widespread media coverage across multiple reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and prompts public debate. Global policy changes must be recognized by at least one of the following: the World Health Organization (WHO), the United Nations (UN), or a consensus among health ministries from at least three G7 countries. The policies or amendments must be aimed at addressing the ethical concerns raised by the controversy and must be implemented on a global scale or adopted by multiple countries across different regions. In the absence of such policy changes, this question resolves as No.

title: Will Amazon engage in a significant geopolitical initiative by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Amazon has officially announced or is credibly reported by at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) to have engaged in a significant geopolitical initiative. A "significant geopolitical initiative" is defined as an action or series of actions by Amazon that significantly affects the geopolitical landscape, including but not limited to: - Establishing a new, large-scale operational presence in a geopolitically strategic location; - Entering into a major partnership or agreement with one or more sovereign nations that has substantial geopolitical implications; - Launching a major initiative aimed at influencing international trade or policy. The initiative must be beyond Amazon's traditional e-commerce, cloud computing, and digital services scope, indicating a strategic shift towards geopolitical engagement. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports must provide detailed evidence of the initiative's nature and significance. Temporary or minor engagements, such as short-term trade agreements or minor operational adjustments, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major geopolitical event significantly impact international soccer tournaments by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted the scheduling, location, participation, or overall conduct of international soccer tournaments. A "major geopolitical event" is defined as an event that involves multiple countries and has widespread international implications, such as a war, significant diplomatic conflict, economic sanctions, or a global health crisis. The impact on soccer tournaments must be confirmed by FIFA or UEFA through official announcements, changes in tournament schedules, relocation of tournament venues, or significant changes in team participation. In the absence of official announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The question will resolve as No if no such event or impact is confirmed by the resolution date.

title: Will the NFL host a game in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the National Football League (NFL) has officially hosted a regular season or playoff game in a country that, as of the resolution date, is under international sanctions imposed by the United Nations, the European Union, the United States, or any combination thereof. The game must be part of the official NFL season schedule, and the sanctions must be in effect both at the time of the announcement and the time of the game. Confirmation must come from official NFL announcements or coverage by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, ESPN). In the event of a game announcement followed by a lifting of sanctions before the game occurs, the question will resolve as No. Temporary or exhibition games do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the NFL implement policies to significantly reduce concussions by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the National Football League (NFL) has officially implemented one or more new policies aimed at significantly reducing the incidence of concussions among players. Significant reduction is defined as a decrease of at least 20% in the reported cases of concussions during the regular season compared to the average of the previous five seasons, as reported by the NFL's official health and safety reports or peer-reviewed scientific research. The implementation of such policies must be confirmed by an official NFL announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (ESPN, Sports Illustrated, The New York Times, The Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or policies applied only in pre-season or for specific events do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will France experience a major social movement leading to significant policy changes by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has experienced a major social movement that leads to significant policy changes. A "major social movement" is defined as a widespread mobilization of people across multiple cities, with sustained activities including but not limited to protests, strikes, or public demonstrations, lasting for at least one month. "Significant policy changes" refer to the implementation of new laws or amendments to existing laws at the national level, which address at least one of the core demands of the social movement. The changes must be recognized and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) or confirmed through official government announcements. In the event of multiple movements, the question resolves as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria. Temporary measures or policies that are reversed within the same governmental term do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major aerospace company announce a breakthrough in environmentally sustainable aviation technology by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major aerospace company announces a breakthrough in environmentally sustainable aviation technology. A "major aerospace company" is defined as one listed among the top 20 aerospace companies by revenue according to the latest available Forbes Global 2000 list or similar authoritative financial ranking. A "breakthrough" must represent a significant advancement in technology that reduces the environmental impact of aviation, such as a substantial reduction in carbon emissions, introduction of non-fossil fuel propulsion systems, or significant improvements in fuel efficiency. The announcement must be verified through official company press releases or confirmation by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). The technology must be beyond the conceptual phase, with clear plans for implementation or testing.

title: Will Elon Musk's companies contribute to a significant breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any company owned or co-owned by Elon Musk has contributed to a significant breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a development that leads to a demonstrable and verifiable increase in the efficiency, sustainability, or scalability of nuclear fusion reactions, sufficient to advance the technology towards practical, commercial energy production. The breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, or recognized by a leading authority in nuclear fusion research, such as the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) or a similar reputable organization. Contributions can include, but are not limited to, technological innovations, funding of critical research, or facilitation of international collaborations aimed at advancing nuclear fusion technology. In the event of ambiguous claims of contribution, the resolution will defer to the consensus of experts in the field. The breakthrough must be publicly acknowledged by the contributing company or by the organization recognizing the breakthrough.

title: Will a new astronomical object with implications for nuclear technology be discovered by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new astronomical object is discovered that has implications for nuclear technology. The discovery must be confirmed through observations or data that suggest a direct application or significant impact on nuclear technology, such as new materials for nuclear fusion, natural nuclear reactors, or phenomena that could lead to advancements in nuclear energy or weaponry. The discovery must be recognized and reported by at least three reputable scientific journals or news organizations (e.g., Nature, Science, BBC Science, The New York Times Science section). In the event that multiple objects are discovered, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries made by both professional and amateur astronomers are eligible, provided they are validated by the scientific community.

title: Will there be a major nuclear accident reported in the news by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major nuclear accident is reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). A 'major nuclear accident' is defined as an event classified at Level 5 or above on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), indicating wider consequences beyond the immediate site of the incident. The accident must be confirmed by official sources or through detailed reports from the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of conflicting reports about the severity of the incident, the question will resolve based on the consensus of coverage by the specified news outlets. Temporary or controlled releases of radioactive material not classified as Level 5 or above by the INES do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a significant discovery in particle physics be made through computational methods by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in particle physics is made through computational methods. A "significant discovery" is defined as one that leads to a substantial revision of the Standard Model of particle physics or provides conclusive evidence for phenomena not predicted by the Standard Model. The discovery must be confirmed by experimental results and recognized by a consensus within the scientific community. Recognition can come from publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact (e.g., Nature, Science, Physical Review Letters) and subsequent citation by other significant works in the field. Computational methods include, but are not limited to, simulations, data analysis, and machine learning techniques. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries announced but not yet confirmed by experimental evidence by the resolution date will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a new algorithm significantly improve the efficiency of medical data analysis by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new algorithm is developed that significantly improves the efficiency of medical data analysis. "Significantly improve" is defined as achieving at least a 30% reduction in processing time or a 30% increase in accuracy, compared to the best-known methods as of 2023, without a corresponding increase in computational cost. The improvement must be demonstrated through peer-reviewed research published in a reputable scientific or medical journal, or presented at a major medical or computational science conference. The algorithm must be applicable to a broad range of medical data types, including but not limited to electronic health records, imaging data, and genomic data. In the event of multiple algorithms meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first published or presented evidence. The resolution will default to No if no such algorithm is developed by the specified date.

title: Will Japan lead the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Japan is recognized as the leading nation in the development of a groundbreaking computing technology. Groundbreaking computing technology is defined as a technology that significantly advances the field of computing, either through innovation in hardware, software, or both, and has a global impact on the industry or research. Recognition can come from:
- Official awards or recognitions by international technology organizations or associations.
- Publication of research in leading scientific journals that credits Japan or a Japanese entity (e.g., university, corporation) as the primary contributor to the technology's development.
- Adoption of the technology by major global technology companies or incorporation into international standards.

In the event of a dispute over what constitutes 'groundbreaking', the consensus of experts in the field, as reported by reputable technology news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, IEEE Spectrum) or scientific publications, will be used to resolve the question.

title: Will Australia commission a new nuclear power plant by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Australia has officially commissioned a new nuclear power plant. Commissioning is defined as the process of bringing a new nuclear power plant into operation after construction, including testing all technical systems, ensuring safety measures are in place, and obtaining all necessary regulatory approvals. The plant must be capable of generating power and connected to the national grid. Official commissioning must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. For the purpose of this question, "new" refers to a nuclear power plant that has not been previously operational, regardless of the start date of its construction. In the event of a partial commissioning (e.g., some reactors operational while others are still under construction), the question will resolve as Yes if the operational parts of the plant are generating power and connected to the national grid.

title: Will OpenAI develop an AI model capable of predicting nuclear accidents before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, OpenAI has developed and publicly announced an artificial intelligence model capable of predicting nuclear accidents with a proven accuracy rate of at least 90%. The model must be able to predict accidents at least 48 hours before they occur, allowing for preventive measures to be taken. The prediction accuracy and capabilities must be verified by an independent scientific review or a peer-reviewed publication. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the development of such a model. The AI model must be operational and not in a trial phase. Predictions made by the model that lead to the prevention of a potential nuclear accident will also contribute to the resolution of this question as Yes.

title: Will advancements in string theory lead to a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2040?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, advancements in string theory have directly contributed to a significant breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a development that enables a substantial increase in the efficiency, sustainability, or feasibility of nuclear fusion as a power source, such that it leads to either:
- The construction and successful operation of a nuclear fusion reactor that achieves net positive energy output for a continuous period of at least 6 months.
- The development and validation of a new nuclear fusion technology or material that demonstrably increases the efficiency or reduces the cost of fusion energy production by at least 30%, as confirmed by peer-reviewed scientific research or an official announcement from a recognized authority in nuclear fusion research (e.g., ITER, National Ignition Facility).

Advancements in string theory must be cited as a critical factor in the breakthrough, with evidence provided by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official statement from a leading research institution involved in the breakthrough. In the absence of such direct evidence, consensus among experts in the field, as reported by reputable science news outlets (e.g., Nature, Science, IEEE Spectrum), will be considered sufficient.

title: Will the US Congress pass a major electoral reform bill before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the US Congress passes a major electoral reform bill. A "major electoral reform bill" is defined as legislation that includes significant changes to at least two of the following areas: voting methods, redistricting processes, campaign finance regulations, or voter registration processes. The bill must be signed into law by the President of the United States. For the purposes of this question, "significant changes" are those that alter the federal electoral process in a way that is widely recognized by major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, The Guardian) and political science experts as having the potential to substantially affect the outcome of federal elections. In the event that multiple bills are passed, the question will resolve as Yes if any single bill meets the above criteria. If the bill is vetoed or otherwise does not become law, the question will resolve as No. In the case of ambiguity regarding the significance of the reforms, the consensus among major news organizations and political science experts will be used to determine the outcome.

title: Will a significant electoral reform be implemented in any country as a result of a major food safety scandal before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a significant electoral reform is implemented in any country directly as a result of a major food safety scandal. A "significant electoral reform" is defined as a change in the electoral system or voting process that affects national elections, including but not limited to changes in voting methods, electoral district reconfiguration, or eligibility criteria modifications. A "major food safety scandal" must involve widespread public health concerns, significant economic impact, or substantial political fallout, and must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). The causal link between the food safety scandal and the electoral reform must be clearly documented by credible sources. In the event of multiple reforms in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one reform meets these criteria. Temporary measures or reforms limited to local elections do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major epidemic influence the outcome of a national election in any country before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a major epidemic significantly influences the outcome of a national election in any country. A "major epidemic" is defined as an outbreak of disease that results in a significant number of cases above the expected baseline within that country, and is recognized as such by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the national public health authority of the country in question. The influence on the election outcome must be clearly attributable to the epidemic, such as through a substantial shift in voter behavior, the implementation of emergency voting measures (e.g., widespread mail-in voting, election postponement), or significant changes in the political landscape directly related to the epidemic's impact. The determination of "significant influence" will be based on analysis from at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or a consensus among political analysts. In the event of multiple epidemics influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first verified instance.

title: Will a landmark legal case involving immunology be adjudicated by the Supreme Court before 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the Supreme Court of the United States adjudicates a landmark legal case involving immunology. A "landmark legal case" is defined as a case that: 
- Has significant implications for the field of immunology, potentially altering legal standards, practices, or understanding within the field; 
- Is widely covered by major legal analysis platforms and recognized by experts in the field of immunology and law as having landmark status. 

For the purpose of this question, "adjudicated" means that the Supreme Court has issued a final ruling on the case, not including any potential remands to lower courts for further proceedings. 

In the event that multiple cases could meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes upon the adjudication of the first such case. 

Sources for confirmation include official Supreme Court announcements, major legal reporting outlets (e.g., SCOTUSblog, LexisNexis), and reputable news organizations.

title: Will a significant legal discovery in astronomy lead to a new international space law by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant legal discovery in the field of astronomy leads to the establishment of a new international space law. A "significant legal discovery" refers to a finding or event that necessitates the creation, amendment, or expansion of legal frameworks governing space exploration, utilization, or security. The new law must be officially adopted by an international governing body recognized for space affairs, such as the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (COPUOS) or an equivalent entity. The adoption of the law must be documented by official records or announcements from the governing body. In the absence of direct announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The law must address issues directly stemming from the discovery and must be applicable internationally, not limited to specific countries or regions. In the event of multiple discoveries leading to separate laws, the question will resolve as Yes upon the adoption of the first such law.

title: Will the US Congress pass a major law reforming the judicial system before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the US Congress passes a major law aimed at reforming the judicial system. A "major law" is defined as legislation that introduces significant changes or additions to the structure, function, or processes of the federal judicial system, including but not limited to changes in sentencing guidelines, court procedures, judicial appointments, or the rights of defendants. The passage of the law must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. For the purpose of this question, minor amendments, resolutions, or executive orders do not qualify as a "major law." In the event of ambiguity regarding the significance of the law, the resolution will be based on the consensus of legal experts as reported by the aforementioned news organizations.

title: Will an NBA player break the single-game scoring record by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, an NBA player breaks the current single-game scoring record of 100 points, set by Wilt Chamberlain on March 2, 1962. The new record must be officially recognized by the National Basketball Association (NBA) and must occur during a regular season or playoff game. Exhibition, pre-season, and All-Star games are excluded. The game in which the record is broken must be completed, and the score must be validated by the NBA. In the event of a tie, where multiple players break the record in the same game, the question will resolve as Yes. If the record is broken in a game that is later annulled or the performance is disqualified for any reason by the NBA, the question will not resolve as Yes.

title: Will a major Hollywood movie about Scott Alexander's work be announced by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major Hollywood studio (defined as one of the members of the Motion Picture Association as of 2023) officially announces the development of a movie based on the work of Scott Alexander. The announcement must specify that the movie is based on either a specific blog post, article, or book written by Scott Alexander. Confirmation can come from an official press release, a statement from the studio, or coverage in at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Los Angeles Times). The movie must be intended for theatrical release, not solely for streaming platforms. In the event of an ambiguous announcement, the question will resolve as Yes only if further details confirm the movie's direct relation to Scott Alexander's work. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, the question resolves as No.

title: Will biotechnology significantly enhance athlete performance in any major sports league by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any major sports league (e.g., NFL, NBA, MLB, NHL, FIFA, etc.) has officially recognized the use of biotechnology as a means to enhance athlete performance. Enhancement must be significant, leading to measurable improvements in athlete performance metrics such as speed, strength, endurance, or recovery times. The use of biotechnology must be confirmed by the league's official announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, ESPN) are sufficient. Biotechnology enhancements include, but are not limited to, genetic modifications, bioengineered supplements, or advanced prosthetics that go beyond traditional injury recovery aids. Temporary or experimental use for injury recovery does not count towards this question's resolution. The technology must be integrated into the regular training or rehabilitation protocols for athletes within the league.

title: Will the United Nations announce a new global initiative to combat climate change by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Nations officially announces a new global initiative specifically aimed at combating climate change. The initiative must represent a significant commitment beyond existing agreements and programs, and must be aimed at reducing global greenhouse gas emissions, promoting sustainable development, or enhancing international cooperation on climate change. The announcement must come from an official UN body or a recognized authority within the UN, and be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of a direct announcement, credible documentation of the initiative's approval or implementation by the UN will also suffice. This question resolves as NO if no such initiative is announced by the specified date.

title: Will a major breakthrough in biotechnology significantly reduce carbon emissions by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in biotechnology is officially announced and recognized as having the potential to significantly reduce carbon emissions. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a development in biotechnology that enables a reduction in global carbon emissions by at least 10% from 2020 levels, as reported by the International Energy Agency (IEA) or an equivalent authoritative body. The breakthrough must be applicable on a global scale and not limited to specific regions or industries. The announcement must come from a credible scientific institution, a government body, or be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of such an announcement, credible scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals that are widely recognized in the field of biotechnology and climate science will also be considered. The breakthrough must be demonstrable and verifiable, with clear evidence of its potential impact on carbon emissions. In the event of multiple claims, the resolution will be based on the consensus of the scientific community or the most authoritative evidence available.

title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly linked to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health due to climate-related disasters; - Effects on respiratory and cardiovascular health from air pollution; - Risks associated with extreme weather events. The report must be publicly accessible and can be either a new publication or an update to an existing report. It must be recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change health impacts. In the absence of a direct publication by the CDC, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the CDC's involvement in a comprehensive study or report on this topic will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The question will resolve as No if such a report has not been published by the specified date.

title: Will a quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
body: A "quantum computing breakthrough" refers to a significant development in quantum computing technology that enables the solving of complex problems in the natural sciences (e.g., physics, chemistry, biology) that were previously infeasible or extremely time-consuming with classical computing methods. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a documented case where quantum computing technology has been applied to solve a complex natural science problem, leading to a significant advancement in the field. The advancement must be recognized and validated by the scientific community, with findings published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference. The problem solved must be one that is widely acknowledged by the scientific community as complex and significant. In the absence of direct publication, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the breakthrough and its application in solving a complex natural science problem are sufficient. The question resolves as NO if such a breakthrough has not been documented by the specified date.

title: Will a significant discovery in the field of natural sciences be influenced by research funded by the Virginia Department of Health by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in the field of natural sciences is announced and recognized as being influenced by research funded by the Virginia Department of Health. A "significant discovery" is defined as a finding that leads to a notable advancement in understanding, technology, or methodology within any of the natural sciences (biology, chemistry, physics, earth science, astronomy, etc.), and must meet the following criteria:

- The discovery is published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference.
- The publication or presentation explicitly acknowledges funding or support from the Virginia Department of Health.
- The discovery is recognized by the scientific community as a notable advancement, as evidenced by citations, awards, or public recognition by reputable scientific organizations.

In the event that multiple discoveries meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of them does so by the specified date. If no such discovery is announced by this date, the question resolves as No.

title: Will Amazon's involvement in cloud computing significantly accelerate research in the natural sciences by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is significant evidence that Amazon's involvement in cloud computing has accelerated research in the natural sciences. Significant acceleration is defined as:
- A measurable increase in the number of peer-reviewed scientific publications in the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, and earth sciences, attributable to the use of Amazon's cloud computing resources, compared to the five-year period prior to 2021.
- Public acknowledgment from at least three major scientific institutions or organizations that Amazon's cloud computing services have substantially contributed to advancing their research.

Evidence must come from reputable sources, including peer-reviewed scientific journals, official statements from scientific institutions, or reports from major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of direct evidence, credible data showing a correlation between Amazon's cloud computing services and research output in the natural sciences will be considered.

This question does not consider indirect contributions, such as general improvements in computing technology or financial donations to scientific research.
